EDUCATIONAL
CULTURAL
BROADCASTING
COMMISSION
MARYLAND
NEWS RELEASE
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
JULY 24, 1968
MARYLAND E7V NAMES
EXECUTIVE PRODUCER FOR URBAN AFFAIRS
The appointment of Walter S. Brooks as Executive Producer for
Urban Affairs was announced today by Dr. Frederick Breitenfeld, Jr.,
Director of the Maryland Educational Cultural Broadcasting Commission.
Mr. Brooks was formerly National Target City Project Director for the
Congress of Racial Equality*
Mr. Brooks is expected to work closely with the people and
organizations in Maryland*s urban communities, establishing and
linking their activities and interests to program development at
the Maryland Center for Public Broadcasting now under construction
in Owings Mills# His exclusive concern with urban problems and
his four part role as producer, production supervisor, talent scout,
and coordinator of organized group viewing and "follow-up"* make
his position with Maryland ETV a "first" in the nation.
A native of Havre de Grace and a graduate of Ansonia High
School, Ansonia, Connecticut, Mr. Brooks served in the Air Force
and the Post Office Department before becoming active in the civil
rights movement.
Since i960 he has participated in CORE, NAACP, SCLC and SNCC
activities in Maryland, Alabama, Mississippi and the Northeast. From
Chairman of the New Haven, Connecticut Chapter of CORE in I96I, he rose
to national leadership in I965 as Field Secretary for CORE.
In 1966 Mr. Brooks was appointed National Target City Project
Director for Baltimore and a member of CORE*s Executive Council. In
Baltimore he was instrumental in arranging for the funding of training
programs for inner city residents and for the improvement of communication
between the Black community and the city.
In making today*s announcement Dr. Breitenfeld said, "Mr. Brooks1
position as Executive Producer will give him the responsibility and
freedom we believe are essential to his serving Public Broadcasting in
Maryland in the identification of needs and the development of programs
to serve the urban community."
First broadcasts from the Maryland Center for Public Broadcasting
are scheduled for next spring.
